question: B 03
sols_html:
Following the hint, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = 5x^{4} - 5x^{3} = 5x^{3}(x-1)\end{aligned}\]

The zeroes of f’ are x = 0, 1.

On \(\displaystyle (-\infty,0)\) (say at \(x = -10\)), \(\displaystyle f'(x) > 0\) and so the function is increasing on this interval.

On \(\displaystyle (0,1)\) (say at \(x = 1/2\)), \(\displaystyle f'(x) < 0\) and so the function is decreasing on this interval.

On \(\displaystyle (1,\infty)\) (say at \(x = 10\)), \(\displaystyle f'(x) > 0\) and so the function is increasing on this interval.

Therefore we have a local maximum at \(\displaystyle {\color{blue} x= 0}\) and a local minimum at\(\displaystyle {\color{blue}x= 1}\).
